sections.text: Use comparative verbs to show how things are similar or different. These verbs are more formal and precise than using 'be similar/different'.
resembles (formal similarity), takes after (family/style), has...in common (shared features), compares to/with (general comparison).
differs from (neutral difference), contrasts with (strong opposition), distinguishes...from (what makes something unique), varies from (changes).

examples.original: Your new design is very similar to the original concept.
This approach is completely different from traditional methods.
Sarah looks just like her mother in appearance.
His conservative views are opposite to her liberal beliefs.
Both languages share many grammatical features.
Superior quality makes this product different from cheaper alternatives.
examples.hint: Use 'distinguishes...from' to show what makes something different

examples.original: We can make a comparison between the two economic systems.
Prices are different depending on location and season.
examples.hint: Use 'vary' to show things change or differ

examples.original: The experimental results match our theoretical predictions exactly.
This smartphone is similar to the latest iPhone in design.

sections.text: Use comparative adjectives (similar to, different from, identical to) with 'be' to describe relationships between things.
Use 'to': similar to, identical to, comparable to, equivalent to, the same as. Exception: 'alike' has no preposition.
Use 'from': different from, distinct from, dissimilar to. Remember: 'different FROM' (not 'different than' in British English).

examples.original: This design resembles the original version.
The two contracts are exactly the same.
examples.hint: Use 'identical' when things are exactly the same

examples.original: Her teaching style doesn't resemble conventional methods at all.
examples.hint: Use 'is different from' to show difference

examples.original: Your conclusion matches mine exactly.
examples.hint: Use 'is the same as' when things match

examples.original: One kilogram equals roughly 2.2 pounds.
examples.hint: Use 'is equivalent to' for equal value

examples.original: Her Australian accent clearly differs from a British one.
examples.hint: Use 'is distinct from' to emphasize clear difference

examples.original: This qualification equals a master's degree.
examples.hint: Use 'is equivalent to' for equal status

examples.original: The twins look very much the same.
examples.hint: Use 'alike' (no preposition) when things resemble each other

examples.original: This price can be compared to last year's rates.
examples.hint: Use 'is comparable to' when things can be compared

examples.original: These findings contrast sharply with earlier studies.
examples.hint: Use 'are different from' to show contrast

sections.text: Shows two things changing together in a parallel way. Pattern: the + comparative + clause, the + comparative + clause.
Connects two positive elements of equal importance. Shows something has two qualities or two things happen together.
Neither...nor: two negative elements. Either...or: choice between two options.

examples.original: When you practice more, you get better results.
examples.answer: The more you practice, the better

examples.original: She speaks French and she also speaks Spanish.
As prices become higher, demand gets lower.
examples.answer: The higher the prices, the lower
examples.hint: Use 'the higher...the lower' for inverse relationship

examples.original: I don't like coffee and I don't like tea either.
If you leave earlier, you'll arrive sooner.
examples.answer: The earlier you leave, the sooner

examples.original: You can pay by card or you can pay in cash.
When she works harder, she feels more satisfied.
examples.answer: The harder she works, the more satisfied

examples.original: The film was entertaining and it was also thought-provoking.
He didn't apologize and he didn't explain either.
examples.hint: Use 'neither...nor' for two actions not done

examples.original: As you learn more, you realize you understand less.
examples.answer: The more you learn, the less
examples.hint: Use 'the more...the less' for inverse realization

sections.text: Use 'whereas' and 'while' to show contrast within one sentence with a comma: X is Y, whereas/while Z is W.
Use 'However', 'Nevertheless', 'Nonetheless' to start a new sentence showing contrast. Always use comma after: Sentence 1. However, sentence 2.
Use 'by/in contrast', 'on the other hand', 'conversely' to show direct opposition or completely opposite situations.

examples.original: Traditional methods are slow but modern techniques are efficient.
examples.hint: Use 'whereas' to contrast in one sentence

examples.original: The project was expensive but it delivered excellent results.
She prefers classical music but her brother loves jazz.
examples.hint: Use 'while' to show contrast within sentence

examples.original: Public transport is affordable but private cars are expensive.
examples.before: Public transport is affordable. Private cars,

examples.original: The task seemed impossible but the team completed it successfully.
Some people enjoy city life but others prefer rural areas.
The theory suggests growth but the data indicates decline.
examples.before: The theory suggests growth. The data,
examples.hint: Use 'on the other hand' to show opposite view

examples.original: Critics praised the film but it didn't succeed commercially.
He's very sociable but his sister is quite reserved.
Prices rose in urban areas but they fell in the countryside.

sections.text: Use 'as...as' for equal comparison. 'Not as...as' shows inequality. Examples: as tall as, as expensive as.
Short adjectives (1-2 syllables): add -er (taller, faster). Long adjectives (3+ syllables): use more (more expensive). Use 'than' after.
Short adjectives: add -est (tallest, fastest). Long adjectives: use most (most expensive). Always use 'the' before superlatives.

examples.original: This phone costs the same as that one.
A laptop has greater convenience compared to a desktop.
No mountain in Europe has greater height than Mont Blanc.
She doesn't run at the same speed as her sister.
This solution shows greater simplicity than the previous one.
No author is more famous than Shakespeare in English literature.
examples.hint: Use 'the most' for superlative of long adjectives

examples.original: Digital books cost a smaller amount compared to printed ones.
The exam was equal in difficulty to last year's.
Summer days have greater length compared to winter days.
This method is more effective than all other approaches.

sections.text: Combine superlatives with present perfect to describe the most extreme experience in your life up to now. Very common in everyday English.
the most/-est + (noun) + subject + have/has ever + past participle. Example: the best film I have ever seen.
Use 'one of the' + superlative + plural noun to show something is among the best/worst. Example: one of the best books.

examples.original: I've never seen a better film than this one.
examples.answer: the best film I have ever seen

examples.original: She's never read a more interesting book than that one.
examples.answer: the most interesting book she has ever read
examples.hint: Use 'the most interesting...she has ever read'

examples.original: We've never had a worse holiday than last summer.
examples.answer: the worst holiday we have ever had

examples.original: I've never visited a more beautiful place than Santorini.
examples.answer: the most beautiful place I have ever visited
examples.hint: Use 'the most beautiful...I have ever visited'

examples.original: He's never given a better presentation than today's.
examples.answer: the best presentation he has ever given

examples.original: They've never faced a more difficult challenge than this project.
examples.answer: the most difficult challenge they have ever faced
examples.hint: Use 'the most difficult...they have ever faced'

examples.original: I've never eaten worse food than at that restaurant.
examples.answer: the worst food I have ever eaten

examples.original: She's never met a kinder person than her neighbor.
examples.answer: the kindest person she has ever met

examples.original: This is among the best concerts I've attended.
examples.answer: one of the best concerts I have ever attended
examples.hint: Use 'one of the best...I have ever attended'

examples.original: That was among the most inspiring speeches I've heard.
examples.answer: one of the most inspiring speeches I have ever heard
examples.hint: Use 'one of the most inspiring...I have ever heard'
